Comments_List: Excellent insight from within the State Department.
Inside knowledge of how the U.S. responds to crises in foreign countries in terms of communication, politics, and engagement of different institutional actors
I learned the extensive nature of responding to crises as an ambassador. I also learned about all the recent events this decade and how the United States would have responded to such events.
How policy professionals respond to crises
Perhaps better direction. At times, we were unsure of what was going on because the Ambassador was not clear.

The course covered a lot of different types of crises and we had some great guest practitioners as well! The beginning of the course felt much more structured than the second half, however, and toward the end it often felt like there wasn't clear direction of what was going on in the class based on the syllabus and communication from the professor.

While this course was interesting and there was a lot of student engagement, I think a lot of the students' learning focused heavily on the student group presentations, student-created simulations, and guest speakers. I took the class hoping to learn directly from Amb. Thomas's experiences, and I think the classes earlier in the semester were more what I expected -- him giving an overview of a crisis and his experience about it and allowing us to ask questions. I think there needs to be fewer student presentations and a greater lecture or discussion component, which I think is missing from this class.
amazing instructor! With an in-depth knowledge of issues and their complexities
